en.question: Medical Orders ๐๐ฃ๏ธโ When is it permitted to receive/give a verbal medication order and how is it performed?
answer: A verbal order is permitted when the authorized physician is occupied in a sterile procedure or action and cannot document the order

Receipt/delivery of a verbal order will be performed using the Read Back method โ repeating aloud the order details and patient details for confirmation and verification of all transmitted and received information.
The nurse will carry out the order and keep the original medication packaging until the end of the procedure.
At the end of the procedure the physician and nurse will document in the patientโs chart the medications given during the procedure and confirm with their signatures.

en.question: Medical Orders ๐๐โ When is it permitted to give/receive a telephone medical order and how is it performed?
answer: In a medical emergency and/or when the physician is occupied in a therapeutic intervention and cannot stop to write the order and/or a physician who is not physically present to write and sign the order (e.g., on-call physician).
Verbal order for chemotherapy or blood/blood products is prohibited.
Receipt/delivery of a telephone order will be performed using the Read Back method:
The nurse will document the order, including the name of the order giver, in the patientโs record in the dedicated component "Telephone Orders".

The physician who gave the telephone order or the treating physician will confirm the medical order as soon as possible upon arrival to the department and no later than the morning physiciansโ round the next day.

en.question: Laboratory ๐งช๐จโ What are critical (panic) results in diagnostic tests?
answer: Abnormal results indicating high risk or immediate life-threatening danger to the patient that require immediate reporting to the treating physician.
Critical values/conditions have been defined in diagnostic tests: laboratories, microbiology, imaging, nuclear medicine, ergometry, echocardiography, obstetric ultrasound, fetal monitoring, EEG.

en.question: Communication ๐ฃ๐โ What is the model according to which information is transferred between caregivers in the organization and what are its components?
answer: The goal โ to improve continuity of care by structuring the way information is transferred and maximizing accuracy of the transmitted details
INTRODUCTION (self-introduction โ presentation of the caregiver). Who are you, what is your role, where are you located?
SITUATION (situation description) What is the current problem?
BACKGROUND (background description) Clinical background of the discussed patient and important information details for decision-making.
ASSESSMENT (assessment and evaluation) What do you assess the problem to be?
RECOMMENDATION (recommendations) What is your recommendation for continued patient care / solution of the presented problem

en.question: High-Risk Medications ๐โ๏ธโ What is the group of "high-alert" medications?
answer: High-alert medications are drugs that may cause harm to the patient regardless of the route of administration even if given according to the rules.
Medications whose incorrect use (deviation from recommended dosage, frequency, rate or route of administration) involves an increased risk of causing significant harm to the patient
Examples: chemotherapeutic agents, insulin, concentrated electrolytes, drugs with a narrow therapeutic index
Concentrated electrolytes constitute a sub-group requiring separate locked storage

en.question: Patient Admission ๐ฅ๐โ How to act upon admission of a patient in the outpatient clinic/ambulatory setting and if more than 30 days have passed from the admission in this setting to the patientโs admission to the department?
answer: *If more than 30 days have passed from the date of the initial assessment of the patient performed in the outpatient clinic/ambulatory unit until the patientโs admission to hospitalization, a repeated review of the patientโs medical history and a repeated physical examination, assessments of his function and update on any change in his condition must be performed.
The repeated assessment and changes in the patientโs condition will be documented by the physician and nurse in the patientโs record upon the patientโs arrival to the inpatient department.

*In medical assessments performed and documented within the 30-day range before hospitalization, any significant change in the patientโs condition and in his assessment must be noted at the time of admission to hospitalization.

en.question: Glucose Monitoring ๐ฉธ๐โ At what frequency / how many times a day should glucose be measured for a diabetic patient? And when?
answer: For a diabetic patient receiving oral medication โ on the first day 3 times a day (before meals or at other times according to medical discretion).
If glucose level is within the desired range โ monitor once a day.
If there is a change in condition or medication change โ continue 3 times a day.
Insulin treatment โ blood sample for glucose before meal and before insulin administration.

en.question: Pressure Ulcers ๐โ๏ธโ When should a risk assessment for pressure ulcer development (Norton/Braden) be performed and an intervention plan implemented?
answer: Risk assessment for pressure ulcer development โ for every patient up to 8 hours from admission and in every change of condition.

Children: child with Braden or Braden Q score 15 and below โ daily intervention plan + intervention once per shift.

en.question: Physical Restraints ๐ง๐จโโ๏ธโ Who has the authority to give an order for physical restraint of a patient / release of freedom of movement and what is its validity?
answer: Authority: department physician and/or qualified nurse responsible for the shift only.
Order for physical restraint every 8 hours, medical approval for continuation of physical restraint after 24 hours.

en.question: Sedation ๐ด๐ For a patient who underwent sedation, vital signs were taken during the procedure and documented in the medical chart according to the procedure:
answer: The patient will be under continuous monitoring and observation from the moment of administration of the sedation medication until his discharge.

โขMonitoring and observation will include: maintaining direct eye contact and continuous clinical monitoring of the following parameters: level of consciousness, patientโs color, chest movements and respiratory rate.
โขMeasurement of heart rate (in adults) and blood oxygen saturation by continuous monitoring. Blood pressure will be measured every 5 minutes
โขChecking additional parameters, in children blood pressure and temperature, according to the order of the responsible physician.
Documentation of the parameters by a qualified nurse in the record at least once every 10 minutes.

en.question: Sedation ๐ด๐ For a patient who underwent sedation, vital signs were taken during recovery/awakening and documented in the medical chart according to the procedure:
answer: In children โ monitoring during awakening will include:

โขMonitoring and documentation of level of consciousness every 15 minutes
โขMonitoring of additional parameters according to medical order.
In adults โ monitoring of the patient during awakening will include assessment of vital signs: blood pressure, pulse, blood oxygen saturation, level of consciousness, pain assessment.
The parameters will be checked at least upon patient admission and before his discharge

en.question: Sedation ๐ด๐โ What does patient discharge from recovery/awakening include?
answer: Patient discharge will be according to the order of the responsible physician and provided the following conditions according to the Aldrete scale are met:
1. Level of consciousness appropriate to age and patientโs condition before the procedure,
2. Hemodynamically and respiratory stable according to age and patientโs condition before the procedure,
4. In children discharge when the patient is pain-free and accompanied by an adult only,
5. The patient will receive an explanation about the prolonged effect of the treatment including prohibition of driving and importance of accompaniment by an additional adult,
6. A hospitalized patient will be transferred to the department accompanied by a stretcher-bearer; nurse and/or physician accompaniment will be at the discretion of the treating physician.

en.question: Sedation ๐ดโฑ๏ธโ What is the required supervision time after sedation?
answer: 1. An ambulatory patient who arrived accompanied will stay in recovery according to his clinical condition and at least one hour after the end of the procedure; if he arrived alone he will stay at least two hours.
2. A hospitalized patient will stay under supervision for at least 30 minutes from his awakening and according to his clinical condition.
According to the MPADS scale โ the patient is discharged home or to the department with a score of 9-10 and according to his previous condition (without deterioration).

en.question: Adverse Events ๐จโ๏ธโ What is the definition of a near miss and what to do with a near-miss case?
answer: Definition of a near miss โ a failure in treatment, or an error identified before or during performance, that was prevented and did not cause actual harm to the patient.
These events have great educational value and constitute a systemic opportunity to improve treatment safety.
There is great importance in increasing the number of near-miss reports over the number of adverse event reports and thereby preventing the next event.
In every near-miss case the event must be checked or investigated and conclusions drawn accordingly, in order to prevent the next event.

en.question: Patient Marking ๐ฅ๐โ When will a patient be marked?

en.question: Fire Safety ๐ฅ๐งฏ All staff members know how to report the location of a fire extinguisher and rules of conduct in case of fire
answer: *In any suspicion of an event (visible fire, smoke, smell) in the department or upon hearing alarm detectors as a warning of fire outbreak in the department, split teams to locate and immediately verify the exact location.
*Whoever discovered the fire: remove people in the fire/smoke area โ patients and visitors.
*Extinguish the fire independently using the firefighting equipment available in the department.
*Update the event manager in the department
*Department event manager: call security center 8100 or alternatively activate the fire button.
*Senior person on site: during regular working hours โ hospital management. During on-call hours โ the general nurse.

en.question: Ventilation ๐ฅ๐โ Does the staff know โ to which electrical socket will the ventilator be connected?
answer: The ventilator is defined as the most vital device whose activity must be prevented from stopping during a power outage.
For this purpose, ventilators must be connected to the UPS system (blue sockets).
In a situation where there is no / the UPS socket is not found, the device will be connected to the socket connected to the generator (red sockets).
The ventilator will be connected preferably to a blue socket or a red socket marked with the inscription โfloating networkโ.

en.question: Catheters ๐๐โ In which cases is there a need to replace a central catheter?
answer: Removal / replacement of catheter in cases of infection at the catheter insertion site, or suspicion of sepsis.
